headers.access-control-expose-headers: ETag, Link, Location, Retry-After, X-GitHub-OTP, X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Used, X-RateLimit-Resource, X-RateLimit-Reset, X-OAuth-Scopes, X-Accepted-OAuth-Scopes, X-Poll-Interval, X-GitHub-Media-Type, X-GitHub-SSO, X-GitHub-Request-Id, Deprecation, Sunset

nodes.body:
Thanks for the question! The two examples tap into different layers of the stream:

- stream_function_call_args.py listens to the raw Responses API events (response.output_item.added, response.function_call_arguments.delta, response.output_item.done). That’s the only place you get argument text as it’s being generated, so use this path when you need real-time argument streaming. (see also: https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/function-calling#streaming)
- stream_items.py uses the higher-level Agent "run item" stream. By the time you see tool_call_item, the function name and arguments are already assembled; tool_call_output_item arrives after the tool finishes. No per-character argument deltas are emitted here.

If you just need "which tool was called and what was its result," stick with run_item_stream_event (tool_call_item -> tool_call_output_item). If you need to watch arguments fill in live, keep using raw_response_event with ResponseFunctionCallArgumentsDeltaEvent.

You can also combine both in one loop:

```python
async for event in result.stream_events():
    if event.type == "raw_response_event":
        # start, deltas, done
        ...
    elif event.type == "run_item_stream_event":
        if event.item.type == "tool_call_item":
            print(f"call -> {event.item.raw_item.name}")
        elif event.item.type == "tool_call_output_item":
            print(f"output -> {event.item.output}")
```

Hope this clarifies the differences.

> Thanks for the question! The two examples tap into different layers of the stream:
> 
> * stream_function_call_args.py listens to the raw Responses API events (response.output_item.added, response.function_call_arguments.delta, response.output_item.done). That’s the only place you get argument text as it’s being generated, so use this path when you need real-time argument streaming. (see also: https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/function-calling#streaming)
> * stream_items.py uses the higher-level Agent "run item" stream. By the time you see tool_call_item, the function name and arguments are already assembled; tool_call_output_item arrives after the tool finishes. No per-character argument deltas are emitted here.
> 
> If you just need "which tool was called and what was its result," stick with run_item_stream_event (tool_call_item -> tool_call_output_item). If you need to watch arguments fill in live, keep using raw_response_event with ResponseFunctionCallArgumentsDeltaEvent.
> 
> You can also combine both in one loop:
> 
> async for event in result.stream_events():
>     if event.type == "raw_response_event":
>         # start, deltas, done
>         ...
>     elif event.type == "run_item_stream_event":
>         if event.item.type == "tool_call_item":
>             print(f"call -> {event.item.raw_item.name}")
>         elif event.item.type == "tool_call_output_item":
>             print(f"output -> {event.item.output}")
> Hope this clarifies the differences.

Thank you very much. My current approach is to combine the two.
